unnormalised: **5G Rollout Gains Momentum Across India, Despite Initial Hurdles**
normalised: **Five G Rollout Gains Momentum Across India, Despite Initial Hurdles**

unnormalised: New Delhi – The nationwide rollout of 5G services continues apace, with major telecom providers expanding their networks across Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities. Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel are leading the charge, aggressively deploying infrastructure in key metropolitan areas such as Mumbai, Delhi, and Bengaluru, as well as extending coverage to smaller cities like Lucknow and Patna.
normalised: New Delhi – The nationwide rollout of five G services continues apace, with major telecom providers expanding their networks across Tier one and Tier two cities. Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel are leading the charge, aggressively deploying infrastructure in key metropolitan areas such as Mumbai, Delhi, and Bengaluru, as well as extending coverage to smaller cities like Lucknow and Patna.

unnormalised: While initial adoption faced challenges related to handset compatibility and awareness, analysts at the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi project significant growth in 5G subscribers by Q4 2024. Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) data indicates average 5G download speeds are approximately 10 times faster than existing 4G networks.
normalised: While initial adoption faced challenges related to handset compatibility and awareness, analysts at the Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Delhi project significant growth in five G subscribers by Q four two thousand and twenty four. Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (T R A I) data indicates average five G download speeds are approximately ten times faster than existing four G networks.

unnormalised: "The benefits of 5G, like enhanced connectivity for ‘Swades’-style rural development initiatives, are undeniable," stated a Ministry of Communications spokesperson. The government aims to cover 80% of the country with 5G by the end of 2024, investing Rs. 36,000 crores in network upgrades. Challenges remain in remote areas and hilly terrains, with infrastructure deployments facing logistical hurdles. The deployment of an additional 20,000 km of optical fibre cable is crucial to support the bandwidth-intensive technology.
normalised: "The benefits of five G, like enhanced connectivity for ‘Swades’-style rural development initiatives, are undeniable," stated a Ministry of Communications spokesperson. The government aims to cover eighty percent of the country with five G by the end of two thousand and twenty four, investing rupee thirty six thousand crores in network upgrades. Challenges remain in remote areas and hilly terrains, with infrastructure deployments facing logistical hurdles. The deployment of an additional twenty thousand kilometer of optical fibre cable is crucial to support the bandwidth-intensive technology.
